Early Access Review

I invested relatively early in the development of Boundless (then called Oort Online) because I was impressed with the development team. As a developer myself, I understand that it takes quite a lot of vision, planning and strict quality control to create a game like this. I saw a high level of creativity (and consistency) along with a real dedication to quality and transparency in the game's forum. That was impressive and I knew this team could create something unique.

At the moment, the game itself is a ton of fun if you enjoy exploration and building. There's not currently a lot of the more advanced game play features like economy, farming, trade progression, etc. but I've learned a lot about what the team has planned for the near future and it looks very promising.

The latest big update included a much improved user experience, player models, expanded crafting, tool models, lighting fixes, expanded weather, etc. The game was already very beautiful and has only become more so.

With the recent announcement of support by Sony to make Boundless a PC and Playstation-only game, I'm excited to see where this team takes the game.

Early Access Review

One of the biggest concerns I see is that people think this is a minecraft clone. What no one really gets is that voxel building games have morphed into their own category of game. This game is similar to minecraft in that there are blocks, and you mine / craft / build with those blocks. That's about where the similarity ends. Legitimately great games like this one get canned all the time just because they're voxel games, and I for one hope this one makes it through. Minecraft was a great game, but it also had it's flaws. This game fixes a lot of the complaints I had about minecraft, and then goes on to implement some amazing and promising systems.

The movement in this game is stellar, and that coupled with the amazing ambient sounds and whooshing that you get when you move fast makesan immersive feel that is pretty awesome. The smoothness of flying through the air on a grapling hook is amazing. The customizability of the terrain is another great feature of this game. There's a lot more options for great landscapes than there were in minecraft's procedurally generated stuff. Overall oort is already a better game than minecraft and deserves to reach fruition.

This game has a strong group of devs working very hard and pushing out new updates rapidly (and it looks completely gorgeous). That, more than anything else, is why i chose to buy this game in early access. There's a really nice feel to the game right now, and the community is great, mostly because of how responsive and interactive the devs are. That is why i feel this game will be here to stay, and will reach it's final form (which will be glorious). Buying in now will give you the opportunity to help sculpt this game into something amazing (even better than it already is)!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to try and keep this short, but still properly cover my initial experiences in this game. Coming in, I was really expecting another minecrap clone, but while at first glance that's what it is, it has a distinctly different feel to it. There are a lot of fun concepts and mechanics present that set it apart from any other games in this rapidly expanding genre.

Here's what I noticed in my first hour or so into the game:
The first thing anyone will notice when playing this is the most obvious; the graphics.
The visuals can be incredible, and somewhat surreal at times, but while they look nice, in all honesty it can get to a point where it slightly hurts the eyes, and can get very distracting. This is honestly one of my biggest irritations with the game, aside from the next point;
Harvesting materials is infuriatingly tedious. I spent what felt like over 30 minutes harvesting one tree, simply because I had to spend so long trying to clear the floating leaves out.
There's a lot, and I mean a LOT of bugs. I found an infinite wood exploit entirely by accident, and it was executed through what should be a normal part of building.(Note to the developers: Ancient Wood Slabs, yo.)
The servers are GHOST TOWNS. I have yet to even see another player, this entire time. I mean, their structures are omnipresent, but the players themselves? Gone with the wind. HOWEVER...
Now, while all of this is glaringly irritating, something that struck me as odd was that after all that, I realized I was still playing. It took me a moment, but I realized that the game was so damn addicting, even without other players, or properly functioning wooden slabs, it was still amazingly fun.

I've tried to organise why.
The entire idea of random portals sitting in the middle of nowhere leading to the middle of nowhere is absolutely brilliant. The fact that transitions between both sides is seamless is even more brilliant, and helps really immerse you into the world, as instead of just switching servers, (which you could do anyways IF YOU HATE FUN) you can instead choose to use a portal, seamlessly jumping from one server to the next without even so much as a loading screen. You can even see the place from the other side. It adds a lot to the game.
The whole concept of a number of the technical blocks is a lot of fun. The bounce.. jump... trampoline... things... are great fun to play with... assuming you can find a good place to set it all up.

The ambience is absolutely wonderful.
Not really much to say about that one. It just works.

Of all the things I saw that people had built, I sincerely did not see even ONE gigantic ♥♥♥♥, not a single phallic obelisk piercing the heavens, the world was DEVOID of grand towering ding-dongs, plenty of ships but barren of mainsails, lots of afros and not one disco stick, stones all over the place but no excalibur, CLUBS WERE OPEN AND NOT A MEMBER IN SIGHT.
Not. Even. One.

It was amazing.

Whoops, I didnt keep it short.

tl;dr:
Buggy, visuals can make your eyes hurt, nobody playing it, still super fun, and has brilliant ideas and mechanics.

And no giant ♥♥♥♥♥.

NO GIANT ♥♥♥♥♥.

ANYWHERE.

I rate it 8.5/10.

The game is still in development, so there isn’t much to do YET aside from build and explore which won’t amuse everyone.  Keeping that in mind, it's completely playable as it is. So far the building mechanics work great and everything is pretty much bug free. I have built a few biggish things now and haven’t run into any issues. The crafting interface is still somewhat new, so the system isn’t as smooth as it could be yet but it is coming along nicely and is still completely functional.

Variety -  There are some pretty incredible landscapes and everything is varied between worlds, from the color of the grass to the shape of the mountains. So if you ever wanted a glowing wizard tower on top of a giant spiral mountain with purple grass… well there’s probably already a perfect place for that. Everything is so damn pretty!

Updates - I have seen people complain about their frequency or speed but I don’t get it, I have been satisfied with the progress. Textures and lighting have been reworked, character models and creatures have been introduced, new tools and tweaks to building mechanics, a UI overhaul, and probably a lot more that I forgot. So while survival aspects and epic battles might be awhile, they have been creating a pretty solid foundation for everything in the meantime. Also - considering some of the recent announcements it appears things will only speed up from here.

Price - It is more than most EA games, but as the devs explained - “A higher price point attracts people who *really* want to try the game and participate in the development/community.”  This is probably a key reason the community has been so great, the cost itself is a deterrent for the undesireables. Even those that are waiting for more content to play are constantly giving feedback, sharing ideas, and helping shape the game. The forum is flooded with constructive suggestions rather than complaints coming from people who just bought an unfinished game because it was cheap, so good ideas might actually be heard!

I highly recommend this game, but only to a certain crowd (in its current state). If you just want to “buy a game” and aren’t interested in supporting development then you probably shouldn’t buy anything early access, but this one might still be worth checking out if you’re a builder.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So my recommendation comes with some good and some not-so-good:

First the good:

The concept is awesome. If this game meets all the promises made by the devs, it will be the best voxel game on the market. Period. Look at the concept art. Look at the dev pipeline. Multiple races and classes, magic weapons and items, giant roving baddies, and a full crafting and voxel building system! We're talking elements of Minecraft, WoW, and Shadow of the Colossus all in one game.

The graphics are great!

The interconnected portals are a good approach to a multiserver based game. Each server is it's own biome, so inter portal travel will be an important part of the game to acquire certain resources or blocks.

You have a freaking grappling hook!

They recently added a chisel tool for the creation of shaped blocks. The system before was confusing and clunky. The tool makes it an actual physical interaction that grounds shaped blocks into the lore of the game.

Backers get a say in the developement process through surveys about once a quarter.

Ok, now the not-so-good:

The asking price for the game is pretty high for the level of development it's at. I paid it, but I think the devs might get more backers if they made a couple of  pledge packages priced below the 35$ mark that still allowed access to the game. I think a lot of people are weary of paying a high cost for an incomplete game, especially with the risk of the devs abandoning the game.

There are NO models in the game except for 2-3 unanimated placeholder mobs and a torch; but no PC models (your toon is just an orange cude), tool models, or weapon models. Development on this game has been slow (none of the features I mentioned earier are actually IN the game yet) and while they release updates on regular basis, they are small (usually hotfixes) and don't really contain any major content changes.

As I said before, the graphics in the game are great, but nothing you can't get in MC with the right mods. Depth of field is way to shallow and I keep it turned off.

Not really much to do at this point. Crafting is basically non-existant and there's no real adventure element as of now. You can walk around, use your grappling hook, mine some blocks and if you're really patient, you can create some cool stuff like you've seen in the videos. But I personally can't stay on for more than 10-20 minutes or so. It's an MMO, but the multiple servers mean that the people who are online are spread pretty thin, so it's unlikely to encounter another player.

All in all, this game shows a lot of promise and if you're a patient and committed backer who is excited about the vision of the game, then pay the money and get a say in the process. If you're impatient and want a complete game,  then look elsewhere or mod the hell out of Minecraft. As for me, I believe the devs are working as best as they can on this very ambitous project and I'll continue to check in from time to time and hope the funding picks up enough for them to hire a few more people to speed up the process.

Early Alpha Review

The moment you start up the game you see the vision and inspiration of the dev team. This game is clearly not a clone or a quick money grab like we have seen from so many other games. The dev team is putting some really love behind this game and it is utterly beautiful. I am pretty astonished at what they have done in this early Alpha I HIGHLY recommend anyone and everyone that is interested in the Voxel MMO genre that is starting to develop to throw their support behind this game.

Whats the Good
- Absolutely beautiful environments with amazing atmosphere. You really start to get immersed into the game because of the graphics and sound

- Exploration, you can go anywhere and everywhere. The grappling hook adds a really fun angle to the game that lets you move quickly through the immense environment

- The vision of the dev team is translated really well into the game. You can tell they love their work and this game

- The mechanics are solid. Of course Minecraft laid the framework for Voxel games so at this early Alpha state most of the mechanics mimic any other voxel game

- Its on steam, big plus!

Whats the Bad
- At first you are overwhelmed at the shear vastness of the environment. The world is immense and it can be a bit daunting at first

- Lots of unclear block types. The world is alien so you have purple blocks, strange blocks with circles and others. You aren't sure as to what tool to use on what blocks. But it doesn't take much to harvest blocks so it isn't a big deal.

- Performance is a bit slow and you can understand why. My newer gaming laptop handles it well but there are times that performance gets hit and being in early Alpha it is understandable.


Getting the Game
I really don't like pre-ordering games and I like getting into Alphas even less. Too many times the games don't live up to the hype or the game turns into garbage. Heck some devs just abandon the community for a year. I am a huge fan of MMOs, rogue-likes, and voxel based games. Oort has all of these elements and is doing them well in this early Alpha stage. If you want to support the growing voxel MMO genre I would recommend you get into the Alpha. Even if you don't play it that much supporting the dev team will help push this game and genre forward. We need to support developers like this that are making a great game not just another cheap money grab.

If you don't want to invest in the game yet (I understand I really do) then get the word out on social media to create some hype. The more people know about this game the better it will become.


**Highly recommend and look forward to this game ruining my life when it gets released. Kudos to the dev team over at Wonderstruck.

*** PRE-ALPHA REVIEW ***

I'll admit, I first saw Boundless advertised as a new PS4 title, coming in 2016!  I immediately started looking to see what the current price of PS4's was... to my surprise, I found out that the game was in pre-alpha on PC... now, I normally steer relatively clear of early access stuff (even those that I've backed on Kickstarter)... but something about the look, feel and potential of Boundless made me want to buy it.

I'd played minecraft fairly extensively on and off for about 2 years, so I was expecting a game that at least met that calibre of enjoyment and content.  At first, I'll be honest, I was a little disappointed - maybe I was expecting the game to look like the demo video - but then I started getting lost in how visually brilliant it looks, even at this stage of development.  It's not minecraft... it may have gotten it's bare roots from minecraft, but Boundless has certainly evolved beyond that concept and started to carve a new path to become its own game, surrounded by its own lore and a very much involved community with which the developers interact constantly.

I was suitably impressed as the depth of field and the level of detail and other such graphical and gameplay differences that set this upcoming title apart. Yes, it does currently lack content, but you need to remember, this is a pre-alpha title... which now has the backing of Sony to also become a PS4 title in 2016, so development has been ramped up if anything.

If you're looking for a title that is ready to play, won't crash, and has a whole bunch of great content, you should probably steer clear for a little while (but add it to your wish list for later!), however, if you like being involved in an active, friendly community of both gamers and developers, where your comments will be taken on-board, coupled with playing a sandbox game that is taking shape around you and each update is a discovery of new and interesting things, you may want to take a look and see what it's all about... I'm glad I took the plunge, as I can't wait to see what the next update brings!

This review is for a very early version of the game and I shall update the review as major updates are introduced.

Oort online is one of the best games to come out of Early access for a long time. Although it pains me to do it I have to compare it to Minecraft in it's basic gameplay, that being voxal and building. However unlike Minecraft the look of the game is much what you would expect from a modern game. While that gives you a great explination of the basic resource gathering and construction mechanics it doesn't give you even a glimer into the way the game really works so I will try to.

The game is split into servers which are called 'Worlds' and each world is very unique in the way it looks and the types of resources you can find there in. While often players will have a 'Homeworld' to stay in to construct whatever massive building or impressive landscapes it is really intresting and one of the best single features of the games to explore the other worlds to find diffrent blocks for your buildings. However while wondering around a world of ice and snow and then a forest of sky touching trees is amazing in itself one of the best experiences is stumbling across other peoples constructions. I wondered around a world and found a stone bridge followed the bridge which was huge going from the top of a mountain held up by massive stone pillers coming out of a lake. At the end of the bridge I reach a massive days-to-build castle built in a cathedral style with massive glass windows and a huge hall lit with lanterns and a glass ceiling from which the sun streamed through at the right point of the day, the whole thing visable from miles around.
In one world you can find my Shinto Arch towering out of a watery world filled with lakes and mountains and at night the lanterns shimer, lighting it in the darkness.
That if only that makes Oort online not only beautiful for its stunning landscapes but for the buildings others build adding to the overal experience of the game and with the features being planned and readily worked on (Players are kept updates on the work being done which is great) makes Oort online a must buy game even in it's early state.
If you want to wait a bit longer for the game to have more of the freatures planned, add it to your wishlist but I would suggest buying the game right now and even if production stopped right now I would still get hours and hours of enjoyment out of the game easily.
100/10. No joke.

Early Access Review

Even though this game is pre-alpha, it has a LOT going for it. It is incredibly promising, and quite fun even now.

Wonderstruck has laid the foundation for what has the potential for an extremely fun voxel MMO sandbox and RPG. Here's what gets me excited:

* The world generator can generate extremely varied terrain, and it's improving dramatically over time. The hosted worlds (servers) show off many biomes already.

* The voxel engine is quite flexible, with a mix of natural blocks, slopes, crafted blocks and all that. The game is already a creator's paradise (and the community has shown this!)

* The developers are very responsive, and the community is very welcoming. Every time the developers introduce a new mechanic, the community has a lot of fun with it. (For instance, bouncy blocks have led to all sorts of fun things)

* There is a grappling hook; and it is probably the most fun I have had with a movement mechanic in any game.

* The graphics are gorgeous. Seriously. Oort online is in a class of its own. It runs quite well, even with massive draw distances (due to a pretty unique approach to LoD)

REVIEW FROM 2014:

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game. Develepors, if you are reading this, either the cost needs to be drastically reduced, or you need to stop focusing on tiny lil fix-ups like cloud shadows, and focus more on giving more meaning to the game. True, it looks beautiful, and you can build, but that's about it. There's no objective. There's no leveling. There's no models, no creatures, no upgrading, no survival... nothing but a world with really nice looking blocks. I know it's a really early stage in your game's development, but do NOT price the game at $35 as soon as it's on the shelves if there's nothing to do but place blocks and swing around. That's why you don't have more people playing this game: It's a game for rich people with nothing to do other than sit around and build things in games to feel good about themselves, to be blunt. How many commonplace people can afford a game like this, and how many of Them will be disappointed when they don't get their money's worth out of it? I'd say that at the very most, this game needs to be $15. I'm sorry, again, but this is utterly rediculous.
P.S. If the servers are costing you so much, get rid of a few of them. It's not like there's ever gonna be any more than what, 15, 20 people playing at one time.

*EDIT FOR 2015:

It's been over a year since I wrote this review, and only find it fair to look at the progress that the newly named Boundless has taken up, and give a new review. Since I had written this, the Boundless team has achieved NPCs, basic playermodels, better inventory setups, skins and models for weapons and tools, and more. My previous statement of them just making blocks prettier has been built on as well, making much better lighting, realistic environmental sounds, high quality textures, and different shaped blocks for more advanced building. Along with a slight growth of population, world amounts are apparently being toned down, and the focus is starting to shift more to the players than to the environment. I can see now that my $35 were, indeed, well spent, and I now encourage people to try and purchase this game. It is now successfully timeworthy, and has not even reached 1.0. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Once upon a time, the Na'vi evolved into giant teddy bears, equipped with advanced, but still naturalistic technology.  They opened gates to multiple worlds seeding an interstellar empire that, one day, ceased to be.  That was several hundred years ago.

Boundless - formerly Oort Online - is a MMOBlock-Buildy game centered around the ability to find portals to various worlds.  It's pretty much MineCraft with the interdimensional portal mod, only more visually polished and custom-built to host as many people as possible.

Now, elephant in the room: this game is Early Access, and is therefore incomplete.  I bought into it because I liked what I saw, and had read the reviews for both the good and the bad of what the game currently is.  I'm going to rate based on what's in what we've got.  When enough changes happen or the game goes 1.0, I plan to re-review the game

What Works
First, the game looks amazing.  Boundless really pushes what a block-buildy game can look like...the only runner up is the Free-to-Play game Trove in this department.

Also, some of the mechanics are pretty cool.  Early on you can easily craft a Hookshot or a Grappling Hook - as far as I can tell, there's nearly no difference between the two.  Some video game logic applies - apparently, Na'vi technology is so advanced sticks work as expandable rope - but it makes exploring worlds easy, as long as you don't grapple yourself to death, possibly losing lots of materials in the process.

What Does Not Work
First, the menu controls are generally awful.  Escape opens the general MMO menu involving changing settings, leaving the game, etc.  Tab opens the inventory and crafting menus.  As default controls, this is a truly awful setup, because it feels genrally bad to use.  My suggestion would be to take a page from MineCraft and unify the inventory and crafting interfaces under Escape, but add a button that allows you to access the MMO menu.

Second, the crafting system is remarkably shallow, with few things to actually create.  Now, as said before - this is an alpha game, barely out of being a prototype.  I'm aware of that.  However, to retain players, you need more stuff for us to build.  Some melee weapons would be a good start - Wooden and Stone swords are good ideas.  More uses of Gleam"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(TL;DR- Game worth every penny as it is right now. With all the stuff coming, and all the stuff in the works, I can't see why anyone would pass this up.)

My boyfriend and I bought this game two nights ago, and had a blast playing for the rest of both nights. A lot of people bring up Minecraft similarities, and while the building system is similar, there's more to it with this game for sure. Boyfriend and I played a lot of MC, and we already like this game more.

+ The graphics are phenomenal. We really feel our buildings come to life in this game. The textures and shapes of the blocks, paired with the gorgeous atmosphere (sounds, lighting, sky, everything) really make everything pop.

+ Right now, you start with a few different block types in your inventory. You can set it to infinite blocks, so you don't have to spend time gathering. However, I've found a new type of block through exploration, which was really nice.

+ When I needed a break from building, grappling my way around the world was equally as fun. The landscapes are breathtaking, and it was also really fun searching for signs of life. It's so nice stumbling upon a cabin, or a room built into the side of a mountain, or a tower in a valley. Also, exploring other servers has been a blast, too. Some of the structures are mindblowing. :D

+ Right now, all there is to do is build and explore, and I think it's worth the price as is. With all the stuff that's in the works, this game could be huge. I can't even say how excited we are. The team is also very interactive with the community, and patches come out oftem.

+ The only one thing missing as the game is, is playing as a character. All players are orange blocks right now. You forget that pretty much instantly though, as soon as you start to build or explore.


I really could go on and on, but this gets the major points across. I can't wait to see the game and community grow. :)

Early Access Review

OK the quick version:

Would I Recommend? : Not at this time - despite the game having huge promise - Devs seem to be very slow to add any content. -

Whats good: Exapansive Worlds, exploring, lighting effects, volumetric fog, voxel engine.
Whats bad : Nothing that I can really dislike as its sold as pre-alpha with no bells and whistles at the moment.
Caution: - Remember, it is PRE-ALPHA, do not expect a full game, and you will not be disappointed.


The Longer Version

First off, you need to think of this game, as a Pre-Alpha, and not a fully functioning game. I have read some negative reviews comparing the game with minecraft, or saying there are only placeholders for player characters, that there is no crafting etc. So straight away we can say this is not complete, and is not being sold as complete. That is a very important point to remember before you buy. So I am going to review this, as in its current state, and how that measures up to expectations.

I would recommend looking at all the videos, checking YouTube lets plays, and reading the developers site, and doing your research through the steam community. When you have done that, you will have a feel for how this game is at the moment, and what’s coming down the line. It will set your expectations, and if you decide then to jump in and join the community, you will almost certainly NOT be disappointed.

So with that in mind, I am about 5 hours in. I really like what the developer has done so far. The game engine is smooth, really nice to look at, and there is a lot to explore currently. There are lots of player creations you can find, mainly around the capital areas of each world. There are servers globally, East EU, West EU, the United States, and Australia. At the moment, the servers are very quiet, and that’s to be expected, as the player base grows.

There is a lot of work already done here, with the voxel engine, there is a basic blockset, and the minimap is now also in place. Crafting is unlocked, and is on the way. The worlds themselves seem very large, with a really nice day / night cycle, and amazing lighting effects. I have really enjoyed the few hours I have put in, and intend to put in a lot more. This game has huge potential, and as long as it continues to grow, it should be awesome.

One point is the comparison to minecraft. Sure there are similarities, but for one thing everyone exists in the same persistent universe. When the portal system is fully implemented, players will be able to step" through to other worlds

Early Access Review

Buy this game. If you like good looking blocky games with lots of potential then this is the game. Just watch the videos.

I bought the $250 package in December 2014 through Oort Online (included 4 Steam keys at launch + 2 pre-release keys)  because this game looks so awesome, has tons of potential, and I had some extra money in my 2014 gaming budget. The four copies are for my wife, two daughters (9 and 11), and myself.

Last week I shelled out another $70 for two Steam gifts for my 4 and 6 year old boys because my gaming budget was renewed after January 1, 2015 and the boys have been begging for Oort Online (OO) since I showed it to them.

A bit about our voxel gaming history. I bought 4 Minecraft copies from Notch in the alpha. Then two more in beta. Since 2009-2010 timeframe we have hosted our own family Minecraft server on Linux for friends and family. Those 6 purchases have added up to over thousands of hours of family play time (all LAN play in same rooms). After 4+ years of Minecraft playing when I saw the OO in-game videos and feature list l bought into Oort Online. If Oort Online pans out then the investment will be very tiny for the return (thousands of hours, even more than Minecraft). If this game fails then my wife will not approve any more pre-release games.

The game promises:
- LAN / private server options (we love options)
- Native Linux server software
- Multiple races with different attributes
- Trading / economy
- RPG aspects
- Skilled developers (they claim) focused on engine and networking first
- Grapple hook is the best sandbox addition EVER!
- Motivates my kids to get their school work done so they can play more OO.
- Variety (Randomness of worlds, wildlife, fauna, vegetation, etc)
- Robust world generator
- Portals!
- Bouncy blocks!
- Beacons
- Much more...

Current cons (as of Jan 22):
- No re-mapping of keys. I'm left handed and can't play with WASD setup so I have to let my daughters play while I watch.
- Lack of road map features.
- Now that my boys are playing their Steam pre-release versions my daughters are now begging me to get them pre-release keys. The packages on Oort Online have X release keys with < X pre-release keys. That's not very family friendly when I simply wanted to support the devs with a big purchase but now my family can't enjoy pre-release together.

I spend my time watching the boys running around the worlds, sliding, climbing, bouncing, and swinging around like an intoxicated Spider-Man. They really enjoy just moving around and checking stuff out now. We're all patiently awaiting more features to be added.

Maybe in about 5 years, when people say enough with the early access and the game is forced to be released because it gets such negative reviews, it will be ok. Like they will make more money with it as an early access with a bunch of buy this features and slowly drop one little update at a time.

I could be wrong though... It may be great if they actually progress some of the core features they advertise like the character rpg system, the story, and crafting.
